ij Part 

Hitherto 
<s>In the first part of this Essay I have endeavored to make a Collection of all the single 
Vowels and Consonants which are used in any Language, in which If I have not 
Collected all those extant that are, yet in the method I have used therein, I hope I have 
attained nigher to it then any other Collection yet extant.
I therein have also shown the necessity of a new set of Literal Characters, which I here pro 
pose. And first the set of Consonantall Characters are those following and ranged in the 
same method with those in the Table in the first part<\s>

[Table]

<s>The first rank in every file are those I name radicall Characters, the other succee 
ding ranks have each a distinct Character [text?] addition to distinguish the 
one from the other, which causeth some complication in the Character, but 
Yet I Judged it necessary to expres, the same in [text?], which I thought neces 
sary to distinguish in the Table. the more regularly to distinguish them 
from the others and to expres the derivation 
of letters of the same [text?] the one from the other 
The Set of vocal Carracters are those following 

[Table]

and are each to be placed over the Consonant which in expression it follows and 
whereas Som Syllables begin with a Vowel, place the 12th Consonantal Carrac 
ter answering to the hebr: alef, and over the same place the Vowel beginning 
such Syllable.<\s>
This Character may seem somwhat too Complicate for dispatch in ordinary 
writing, but for printing it will be the same with that now used, and I 
only designed it for that <s>use <\s> purpose, but for <s>dispatch <\s> the pen others more Convenient may 
be invented.
To distinguish the Long Vowel from the short, add a prik to the Vocall 
Character.
The 9th.11.12.13.14th vocal Carracters are for want of single Strookes) Compoun 
ded of the first and 2d.
The Diphthongues truly such (as I have before noted in the first part,) may be 
made by the Conjunction of the single vocal Characters in the order as they 
follow, and will be easily distinguished from the 5 foregoing Compoun 
ded characters of the single vowels, because there will not lightly occurr 
any diphthongues Compounded of the first two Vowels.
